This theorem states that given a smooth œÉ-compact manifold `M` with extended distance, if there exists a locally finite family `K` of closed sets, and a family `U` of open sets such that each set in `K` is contained in a corresponding set in `U`, then there exists a positive smooth function `Œ¥` mapping from `M` to nonnegative real numbers. Furthermore, for any `i` and any `x` in `K i`, the closed ball in the extended metric space centered at `x` with radius `Œ¥ x` is contained in `U i`. This theorem is significant in mathematical analysis and manifold theory, where it is often necessary to find such a smooth function `Œ¥` within an open set of a manifold that encapsulates certain properties.

  [inst_5 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_6 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_7 : SigmaCompactSpace M] {K U : Œπ ‚Üí Set M},
  (‚àÄ (i : Œπ), IsClosed (K i)) ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ (i : Œπ), IsOpen (U i)) ‚Üí

        LocallyFinite K ‚Üí
          ‚àÉ Œ¥, (‚àÄ (x : M), 0 < Œ¥ x) ‚àß ‚àÄ (i : Œπ), ‚àÄ x ‚àà K i, EMetric.closedBall x (ENNReal.ofReal (Œ¥ x)) ‚äÜ U i

Furthermore, for any `i` and any `x` in `K i`, the closed ball in the extended metric space centered at `x` with radius `Œ¥ x` is contained in `U i`. This theorem states the `Œµ`-`Œ¥` definition of having an integral in the context of box integrals. Given a type `Œπ`, normed add commutative group `E`, normed space over the real numbers `‚Ñù` and `E`, `F` as another normed add commutative group, a normed space over the real numbers `‚Ñù` and `F`, a box `I`, an integration parameter `l`, a function `f` from `Œπ` to `‚Ñù` to `E`, a volume function `vol`, and a target value `y`, the function `f` has an integral over box `I` with parameters `l` and volume `vol` equal to `y` if and only if for every positive `Œµ`, there exists a function `r` from nonnegative real numbers to real numbers such that for every nonnegative real number `c`, `l.RCond (r c)` holds and for every tagged prepartition `œÄ` of `I`, if `œÄ` is a base set for `I` under `c` and `r c` and `œÄ` is a partition, then the distance between the integral sum of `f` with volume `vol` over `œÄ` and `y` is less than or equal to `Œµ`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œπ : Type u} {E : Type v} {F : Type w} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E]

  BoxIntegral.HasIntegral I l f vol y ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ Œµ > 0,

        (‚àÄ (c : NNReal), l.RCond (r c)) ‚àß
          ‚àÄ (c : NNReal) (œÄ : BoxIntegral.TaggedPrepartition I),
            l.MemBaseSet I c (r c) œÄ ‚Üí œÄ.IsPartition ‚Üí dist (BoxIntegral.integralSum f vol œÄ) y ‚â§ Œµ

docString: This theorem states the `Œµ`-`Œ¥` definition of having an integral in the context of box integrals. Given a type `Œπ`, normed add commutative group `E`, normed space over the real numbers `‚Ñù` and `E`, `F` as another normed add commutative group, a normed space over the real numbers `‚Ñù` and `F`, a box `I`, an integration parameter `l`, a function `f` from `Œπ` to `‚Ñù` to `E`, a volume function `vol`, and a target value `y`, the function `f` has an integral over box `I` with parameters `l` and volume `vol` equal to `y` if and only if for every positive `Œµ`, there exists a function `r` from nonnegative real numbers to real numbers such that for every nonnegative real number `c`, `l.RCond (r c)` holds and for every tagged prepartition `œÄ` of `I`, if `œÄ` is a base set for `I` under `c` and `r c` and `œÄ` is a partition, then the distance between the integral sum of `f` with volume `vol` over `œÄ` and `y` is less than or equal to `Œµ`.
